inlineContent.text: The Assets Library framework is deprecated as of iOS 9.0. Instead, use the Photos framework instead, which in iOS 8.0 and later provides more features and better performance for working with a user’s photo library. For more information, see
classes provide functionality for fetching an asset’s image or video data.

A given asset in the library may have more than one representation. For example, if a camera provides RAW and JPEG versions of an image, the resulting asset will have two representations—one for the RAW file and one for the JPEG file.

abstract.text: Access the assets in a user’s media library.
An
object represents a photo or a video managed by the Photo application.
An
object encapsulates one of the representations of a given
object.
Returns a full resolution CGImage of the representation.
Returns the representation’s dimensions.
Returns a string representing the filename of the representation on disk.
Returns a CGImage representation of the asset.
Returns a CGImage of the representation that is appropriate for displaying full screen.
Copies a specified range of bytes into a given buffer.
Returns a dictionary of dictionaries of metadata for the representation.
Returns the representation’s orientation.
Returns the representation’s scale.
Returns the size in bytes of the file for the representation.
Returns a persistent URL uniquely identifying the representation.
Returns the representation’s UTI.
encapsulates filtering criteria to be used when retrieving assets from a group.
An

object represents an ordered set of the assets managed by the Photos application. The order of the elements is the same as the user sees in the Photos application. An asset can belong to multiple assets groups.
An instance of
provides access to the videos and photos that are under the control of the Photos application.
A representation of an image, video, or Live Photo in the Photos library.
An object that facilitates retrieving or generating preview thumbnails and asset data.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
